request.prompt:
Schreibe mir einen News Artikel mit dem Titel "Cartoonist Paul Pope is more worried about killer robots than AI plagiarism". 
Der Artikel soll etwa 1 Seite lang sein und mit Markdown formatiert sein. Der Titel soll nicht im Artikel enthalten sein, der Artikel soll direkt mit dem ersten Absatz beginnen. Füge ein <!--more--> zwischen dem ersten und zweiten Absatz ein.
Verwende dabei nur Informationen der letzten 7 Tage, sodass der Artikel nur die aktuellen Neuigkeiten zu dem Thema enthält.
Füge am Ende des Artikels einen Absatz mit den verlinkten Quellen hinzu.

args.query: Cartoonist Paul Pope is more worried about killer robots than AI plagiarism news June 2025

Cartoonist Paul Pope is more worried about killer robots than AI plagiarism
===========================================================================

**June 21, 2025:** [Paul Pope: Killer Robots Trump AI Plagiarism Concerns](https://techcrunch.com/2025/06/21/cartoonist-paul-pope-is-more-worried-about-killer-robots-than-ai-plagiarism/) - Renowned cartoonist Paul Pope, famous for his analog style, is making a comeback with new projects like a career-spanning exhibition and an updated art book. Although aware of AI plagiarism in comics, Pope's greater worries are the potential dangers of AI, such as killer robots and surveillance. He maintains a balance between traditional and digital tools, using AI for research purposes rather than creation.  
  
With upcoming releases like his THB comics collection, Pope remains hopeful about human innovation and creativity amidst technological progress.

output.title: Paul Pope: The Greater AI Threat - SUCCESS QUARTERLY
output.text:
Visionary artist Paul Pope reemerges with new projects and an exhibition. He reveals his greater concern about AI isn't art mimicry, but killer robots and pervasive surveillance, all while championing the enduring value of human creativity.. 

Title: Paul Pope: The Greater AI Threat - SUCCESS QUARTERLY | Business, Tech & Trends That Matter

URL Source: https://successquarterly.com/paul-pope-the-greater-ai-threat/

Published Time: 2025-06-22T04:24:38+00:00

Markdown Content:
Paul Pope, the visionary artist behind such breathtaking graphic novels as [“Batman: Year 100”](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batman:_Year_100) and “Battling Boy,” has long captivated readers with his distinctive, almost tactile artwork and narratives that often delve into the unsettling possibilities of a technologically advanced future.

After a decade of relative quiet on the major comics front, Pope is reemerging into the spotlight, not with a roar, but with a series of deliberate “chess moves” designed to reintroduce his formidable talent to the world.

Yet, as the industry grapples with the seismic shifts brought by [generative artificial intelligence](https://successquarterly.com/navigating-the-ai-stock-landscape/), Pope’s primary concern isn’t the digital mimicry of his unique brushstrokes, but something far more chilling: the specter of [killer robots](https://successquarterly.com/cmos-at-the-forefront-of-ai-driven-marketing-revolution/) and [pervasive surveillance](https://successquarterly.com/palantir-stirs-maga-surveillance-fears/).

It’s a surprising pivot in concern from an artist whose work is so rooted in the tangible world of ink and paper, a stark contrast to the pixelated frontier of AI.

Pope’s return is marked by a career-spanning exhibition at the Philippe Labaune Gallery in New York, an expanded art book titled “PulpHope2: The Art of Paul Pope,” and the eagerly anticipated first volume of his self-published science fiction epic, [“THB,”](https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/26208961-thb?ac=1&from_search=true&qid=sTyI6ciVRb&rank=1) due this fall.

These events signal the end of what Pope admits has been a frustrating period. For years, he’s been toiling away on graphic novels — a process he likens to writing a traditional novel, often taking years with the work remaining unseen due to contractual obligations.

He gestures to a substantial stack of unpublished drawings, a testament to a decade of quiet toil.

Pope’s artistic process is famously analog. While he’s incorporated Photoshop for coloring and textures since the early 2000s, and uses it daily for non-creative tasks, his heart remains with the physical act of ink on paper, a purism he holds dear.

He doesn’t claim analog is “objectively better,” recognizing the undeniable advantages of digital tools – a quicker learning curve, the ease of correction, and endless editing possibilities.

Yet, he finds a profound value in the “punishing” nature of [traditional art](https://successquarterly.com/skillwee-ai-for-strategic-business-leadership/). The early struggles with a brush, the humiliating mistakes, the slow, arduous path to mastery – these are not drawbacks, but essential rites of passage that forge an artist’s authority over their craft, allowing them to truly manifest the visions of their mind.

This commitment to the disciplined, physical act of creation feels almost defiant in an age where instant gratification and digital perfection are increasingly the norm.

Pope sees himself as a “torchbearer” for a lineage of masters like Alex Toth, Steve Ditko, Moebius, and Frank Miller, all of whom honed their skills in the traditional medium.

This commitment to the hand-drawn, however, doesn’t translate into Luddite opposition to AI.

Pope, in fact, uses AI regularly for research, leveraging its vast data processing capabilities to unearth obscure biographical details for essays or to refine story structures.

He views it as a “consultant,” albeit one with a propensity for “hallucinations,” often mixing accurate information with fabricated facts.

His pragmatism is evident; he doesn’t rule out using AI where it’s genuinely useful, viewing it as simply another tool in an artist’s expanding arsenal.

Yet, when the conversation turns to the current tempest engulfing the creative world – the class-action lawsuits against AI companies for copyright infringement and the viral proliferation of AI-generated images mimicking established artists – Pope’s perspective widens dramatically.

While acknowledging the valid legal and ethical questions surrounding AI’s unlicensed use of existing art, comparing it to the MP3 torrenting of the ’90s, his gaze is fixed on a more profound horizon.

“I’m less concerned about having some random person create some image based on one of my drawings,” he states, “than I am about killer robots and surveillance and drones.”

It’s a chilling echo of his own dystopian visions, particularly [“Batman: Year 100,”](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batma

Paul Pope Returns: Unseen Art, AI Controversy, and a Mysterious New Chapter Await
=================================================================================

on [June 21, 2025](https://westislandblog.com/technology/paul-pope-returns-unseen-art-ai-controversy-and-a-mysterious-new-chapter-await/)

[JoA](https://westislandblog.com/author/joarazi/)

Paul Pope has built a reputation as one of the most celebrated comic book artists and authors of the 21st century, acclaimed for landmark titles such as “Batman: Year 100,” where he portrays Batman standing against a surveillance-ridden dystopia, and “Battling Boy,” a story of an adolescent god setting off on a heroic journey against larger-than-life monsters.

However, it’s been over a decade since Pope last published a major new comic book, a hiatus the artist candidly acknowledged has been trying. Speaking recently, Pope described graphic novel creation as fundamentally different from traditional comics publishing, pointing out that writers typically labor in isolation for years under publishing contracts, unable to share their work publicly until release date. He even gestured toward a large batch of unpublished d

output.title: Cartoonist Paul Pope is more worried about killer robots than AI ...
output.text: But he said he isn’t ruling out taking advantage of AI, which he already uses for research. “I’m less concerned about having some random person create some image based on one of my drawings, than I am about killer robots and surveillance and drones,” he said. The following interview has been edited for length and clarity..

Paul Pope’s Comeback: Unpublished Art, AI Fears, and a Bold New Era for Comics
==============================================================================

Paul Pope returns after a decade with unseen art and new projects, embracing analog techniques amid AI debates. He values creativity and craftsmanship over technology.

Categorized in: [AI News](/all-ai-news-for-ai-news) [Creatives](/all-ai-news-for-creatives)

Published on: Jun 22, 2025

[Become an AI Expert today](#/portal/signup)

Paul Pope Returns: Unseen Art, AI Controversy, and a Mysterious New Chapter
---------------------------------------------------------------------------

Paul Pope, known for iconic works like **Batman: Year 100** and **Battling Boy**, is stepping back into the spotlight after more than a decade without a major comic book release. His absence from the scene has been notable, and he openly admits the process of creating graphic novels is demanding and isolating, often requiring years of work kept under wraps until publication.

Unlike traditional comics, graphic novels involve long stretches of solitary effort under contract restrictions, which means artists and writers can’t share their progress publicly. Pope has a large collection of unpublished drawings, a creative backlog he’s eager to finally share with audiences.

### A New Chapter for Paul Pope

An exhibition at the Philippe Labaune Gallery in New York is now showcasing decades of Pope’s artwork. Alongside this, an expanded second edition of his art book, _PulpHope2: The Art of Paul Pope_, has been released. Later this year, fans can look forward to a new collection of his classic self-published sci-fi series, **THB**.

These moves are part of a deliberate plan to reconnect with his audience, though

result.content:
Paul Pope, der gefeierte Cartoonist hinter ikonischen Werken wie "Batman: Year 100" und "Battling Boy", hat kürzlich seine Bedenken über die Bedrohungen durch künstliche Intelligenz geäußert. Während viele Künstler sich Sorgen über Plagiate durch KI machen, sieht Pope eine viel größere Gefahr in der Entwicklung von Killerrobotern und Überwachungstechnologien. In einem Interview betonte er, dass er weniger besorgt darüber sei, dass jemand zufällig ein Bild in seinem Stil erstellt, als über die potenziellen Gefahren, die von autonomen Waffen und allgegenwärtiger Überwachung ausgehen【2-0】【2-1】.

<!--more-->

Pope, der für seine analoge Arbeitsweise bekannt ist, kehrt mit neuen Projekten und einer umfassenden Ausstellung ins Rampenlicht zurück. Trotz seiner Vorliebe für traditionelle Techniken nutzt er KI für Recherchezwecke und sieht sie als nützliches Werkzeug, solange sie richtig eingesetzt wird. Er bleibt jedoch skeptisch gegenüber der unkontrollierten Nutzung von KI und betont die Notwendigkeit, die menschliche Kreativität und Innovation zu schützen【2-2】【2-3】.

In den letzten Jahren hat Pope an einer Vielzahl von unveröffentlichten Zeichnungen gearbeitet, die nun in einer Ausstellung in der Philippe Labaune Gallery in New York zu sehen sind. Zusätzlich wird eine erweiterte Ausgabe seines Kunstbuchs "PulpHope2: The Art of Paul Pope" veröffentlicht, und Fans können sich auf eine neue Sammlung seiner klassischen Sci-Fi-Serie "THB" freuen, die später in diesem Jahr erscheinen soll【2-4】【2-5】.

Pope sieht sich selbst als Fackelträger für eine Generation von Meistern wie Alex Toth, Steve Ditko, Moebius und Frank Miller, die ihre Fähigkeiten in traditionellen Medien verfeinert haben. Trotz der Vorteile digitaler Werkzeuge bleibt er der physischen Kunst treu und betont die Bedeutung der Disziplin und des handwerklichen Könnens, die mit der analogen Kunst einhergehen. Diese Hingabe zur traditionellen Kunstform steht im Kontrast zu seiner pragmatischen Nutzung von KI, die er als Berater betrachtet, der jedoch oft zwischen Fakten und Fiktion schwankt【2-6】【2-7】.

Pope's Rückkehr markiert das Ende einer frustrierenden Periode, in der er an Graphic Novels arbeitete, die aufgrund vertraglicher Verpflichtungen jahrelang unveröffentlicht blieben. Seine neuen Projekte und die Ausstellung sind Teil eines bewussten Plans, sein beeindruckendes Talent wieder ins Bewusstsein der Öffentlichkeit zu rücken und die Bedeutung menschlicher Kreativität in einer zunehmend technologisierten Welt zu betonen【2-8】【2-9】.
